data.title: Dugong
data.meta_description: The Dugong, scientifically known as Dugong dugon, is a fascinating and endangered marine mammal belonging to the order Sirenia. Often referred to as "sea cows" due to their herbivorous diet and grazing behavior, Dugongs are primarily found in the warm coastal waters of the Indo-Pacific region...
data.text:
The Dugong, scientifically known as Dugong dugon, is a fascinating and endangered marine mammal belonging to the order Sirenia. Often referred to as "sea cows" due to their herbivorous diet and grazing behavior, Dugongs are primarily found in the warm coastal waters of the Indo-Pacific region. Here is an in-depth exploration of the Dugong, covering its physical characteristics, habitat, behavior, diet, and conservation status:

Physical Characteristics[]

Size: Dugongs are large marine mammals, with adults typically reaching lengths of 2.5 to 3 meters (8 to 10 feet) and weighing between 200 to 600 kilograms (440 to 1,320 pounds).

Appearance: They have a robust, torpedo-shaped body with thick, wrinkled skin that is typically grayish-brown in color. Dugongs lack hind limbs and have paddle-like front flippers and a powerful tail fluke used for swimming.

Nostrils: Dugongs have large, nostrils located on the upper surface of their snout, which they use for breathing when they surface for air.

Habitat and Distribution[]

Range: Dugongs are primarily found in the shallow coastal waters of the Indo-Pacific region, including the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, and western Pacific Ocean.

Habitat Preferences: They inhabit seagrass meadows, estuaries, and coastal lagoons, where they can find abundant seagrass beds for grazing and shelter.

Behavior and Social Structure[]

Solitary or Small Groups: Dugongs are generally solitary animals, although they may form small groups or "herds" for feeding or mating purposes.

Slow Movements: They are slow-moving animals, typically swimming at speeds of 10 kilometers per hour (6 miles per hour) or less.

Breathing Behavior: Dugongs are obligate breathers, meaning they must come to the surface regularly to breathe air, and they can hold their breath for several minutes when resting or sleeping underwater.

Diet and Feeding Habits[]

Herbivorous Diet: Dugongs are strict herbivores, feeding primarily on seagrasses and occasionally other aquatic vegetation such as algae and mangrove leaves.

Foraging Behavior: They use their specialized lips and teeth to graze on seagrass beds, consuming large quantities of plant material daily to meet their nutritional needs.

Conservation Status and Protection[]
